Beautiful view, cute little garden, an empty dingy tennis court (which will be the perfect spot for me to be horrible at tennis in front of no one), and lots of grass to spread out on and get your tan on.
author: Casi C.

description:
The view!!!

Start out in the Castro and walk up from there (approaching the park from either the south or east...or overshooting and coming back down Roosevelt).  Such a good workout (your buns and thighs will feel it)...and the spectacular view of the city is your reward!

If you have a pooch with you, he's welcome to come along...and even can roam around off-leash in the fenced in dog park.
author: Kimberly G.

description: Good views of Castro, Noe Valley, Mission, SOMA, downtown, Portrero Hills, etc. No tourists. Short hike with or without steps. Some cliff rocks you can sit on.
author: Ken L.

description:
nice area. 
fenced park is small. My dogs got really dirty because there was mud all over the park. 
really nice view of the city. 
You should try to go there and see if your dogs like it. 
one of mine did, the other, not so much...
author: jaime b.

description: This place is pretty cool. Came here today with the dog in tow to check out the dog park. LOVED that its completely fenced in for the dogs to run crazy...wished it was grass though...the mix combo of dirt and bark was alright. With the light on and off sprinkles the pooch wasn't a total mud ball which i was very thankful for. Will definitely come back for more dog park action!
author: Julie F.

description: I love this place. And so does my dog. Two spots for her to play, one that is an official fenced in dog run; and another less official grassy area by the basketball courts. The 360 views, rocks to climb around on, and relatively easy parking also make for a special spot.
author: Katie R.

description:
Panoramic views of the city.  Very windy at the top, and not much grass, as the couple near me found out to their chagrin.  They tried in vain to spread a picnic blanket and then ran away.  The girl kept saying, "Is this it?  Where's the PARK?"  Yes, this is it, and it's spectacular.

That said, she was right: Corona Heights isn't the spot for picnicking or sunbathing  -- head to Dolores Park for that.  But there are great views, and it's walkable from nearby neighborhoods.  The official entrance is on Roosevelt Way -- we tried wandering in up a very steep 16th St. hill and eventually turned around; it turns out you can get to the park trail from there (near the tennis courts) but there's only a very steep narrow dirt path with nothing to hold on to, so you're better off coming up by the gentler path if you're not feeling up to something strenuous and possibly precarious.  But do go.  Ascend the tallest rock and assume a king-of-the-world pose.
author: S P.

description: Was looking for a place to let our new pup run like the wind, but not fear that he would run into the street. Corona Heights met that need. There is a gated area that allows the dogs to run as they please, and a couple benches where the owners can hang out and watch. The view is quite nice. It can get quite chilly and windy up there, even on a nice day so bring your layers folks. The area consists of a bunch of piles of wood chips, which is a bit messy but it is what it is and our dog has fun there. The other people who bring their dogs are friendly and considerate. Yay.
author: Anne Y.

description: One of the best views of San Francisco that you will find. Good for sunrise and sunset.
author: Mo A.

description: I've been wanting to come up here for YEARS and i finally had the opportunity to take a walk up this afternoon. i stared at the view for like 10 minutes just looking around, saying oh there's where i live! and oh there's the safeway, and oh there's where i work! there's dp, and ooo look at the nice roof deck, and there she is the castro theater. i think one of the best views is over to euerka valley b/c that's a vantage view point that you rarely receive in the city. it made me feel cozy looking at the valley. the only bad thing about this park it gets a little windy and it's not very conducive to just hangin out to have a picnic. none the less i'm glad i went!
author: Mikey B W.

description: I am so afraid to let my Prima Pooch run loose here. she is rather free-spirited and obstinate and headstrong and the little bugger doesn't always come when called. what if the baby darts out onto Roosevelt Street and gets her pigheaded self run down ? boyfriend has already told me not to come home if I let some accident befall our baby. so here's what I do: I keep her leashed, she looks with mad envy at the off-leash dogs frolicking about, and I enjoy a beautiful view from atop. then like a crackpot I tell the dog, see, if you knew how to behave you could run around free like the others. then she stands up and scratches at my leg to pick her up and carry her. now THAT is called being trained.
author: Prima D.

description:
Located in my favorite neighborhood in SF, this is easily my favorite park.  I take my spoiled chihuahua to the monthly Chihuahua Cha Cha as often as I can because it's fabulous.  First Sunday of every month from 12-2:30pm tons of little chihuahuas and the like are released like butterflies and allowed to do their little dog dances in the large dog run at the base of the park.  
I have SO many great memories associated with this park, spanning over 10 years.  I took my gay 34 year old hairdresser to my senior ball in 1996 and, since he lived in this neighborhood, we returned here after partying at the Gift Center.  We drank champagne straight from the bottle while sitting on the big red rock under a full moon on one of those rare hot summer SF nights.  Then it got REALLY fun.  We met a group of satanists, argued over the gay/straightness of a guy I thought was hot, Danny kissed the guy proving he was gay, I made out with the guy's unnattractive MUCH older friend, walked off with my "new" friends screaming "It's my senior ball and NO ONE'S going to stop me!", got dragged home by Danny by my pony tail, passed out in bed and didn't wake up until 5pm the next day.
I love you Corona Heights Park.
author: Jill D.

description: Yay! Fenced doggy area for Murphy to run around and make friends. Wonderful view.
author: Howard T.

description: The view in this park is great, and I love it! This is a great spot in the city to spend a nice afternoon during a weekend. Everyone in the city should try!
author: Lisa J.

description: I really luv this place..its all rocky and natural,....its more crowded than it used to be, but its nice to take your sweetie here and look at the view at nite...(but bring a blanket its gets COLD!! and WINDY!!!)
author: Peter S.

description:
It's a huge red rock (some people call it Red Rock) perched above Castro next to the Buena Vista neighborhood, and a pretty spectacular place to have a seat on a breezy, sunny day and watch the city do it's thing. It's a special place for me because I hiked up to it on my first day when I moved here. I had never been to SF before and had only seen some pictures of the city, so I was in full exploration mode. I woke up from the hostel early to walk around, and made a new friend named Christian a couple hours later. He showed me the F Market line, which I thought was the coolest thing. We headed up Market toward Castro on the F-line. At about Octavia street is where the Red Rock comes into view, and I instantly started asking Christian about it. As soon as we got off the F-line, we headed up to there. I'll never forget the feeling that day sitting on that rock. It's a towering lookout in the middle of the city.

It really is an amazing spot, even if it isn't your first day in your new home. Now i live a couple blocks from it, and it's still the number one place I take my SF-newbie friends to see. It's just as nice a park as Tank Hill, but a little more touristy & you have to occasionally pick up after some other jerk's broken beer bottle. For the most part though, the park is in great shape, mostly because the fellow San Franciscans tend to take pride in it. It's also a great spot to sit and watch the downtown fireworks.

The best approach to the peak from Castro is to walk up States Street next to the Gay Cleaners (yes, it's called Gay Cleaners) until you see a small road on your right that leads into a lower park area. There's a switchback path on your left that takes you up to Randall Museum. Go around the back of Randall Museum and you'll find a dirt path that leads you up to the top.
author: Mike W.

description: You can't beat the view of the city from the top of the park.  You can see all of downtown, the Castro, Diamond Heights, etc.  This isn't a big park but it has a lot to offer.  There is a great fenced in dog area as well as an open grassy area.  Also, the park is a short walk from Buena Vista Park.
author: Garrett D.

description: Corona Heights is like the sidekick to Buena Vista Park, and you can make a fine walk by combining the two.  When you see this place from Twin Peaks, it looks strikingly out of place: a very barren and rocky hilltop popping right out of the surrounding neighborhoods.  There's not much else to say about this place, except that it seems to be quite popular with dog owners, and that there's apparently a museum here, the Randall Museum.  I'll definitely have to come back and check it out sometime.
author: Wes M.

description:
did i miss it, or did the collective oeuvre of reviewers exclude mention of how this place is a gay sex/hook-up locale in the wee/naughty hours?  i'm not into random public sex (partly because I'm not into hepatitis, HIV, or any, really, STDs) but I have been demi-stranded with my friend near the tennis courts after after-bars to have a schmig and heard sex-wails (i love a good screamer, but i mean the kind where you think "you should really just go over to Treasure Island to film that aural mess" because you know it would be slightly scarring in person).

IN CASE ALL YOU ZIPCAR/CITYCARSHARE FOLKS DON'T KNOW - YOUR CAR WILL DIE FROM A MERE 20 MINUTES OF MUSIC AND DISCUSSION, SANS HEADLIGHTS, IF THE ENGINE ISN'T RUNNING.  Apparently, those little fob/card readers on the vehicles consume a lot of juice so they die down more easily than one might expect/plan for/desire.  I thought it warranted broadcast to save you an embarrassing cell-yelling volume call at 4 am after hearing BB sex noise and attempting to flee with your friends.

...allegedly.
author: Nathan K.

description:
this is an amazing park with one of the best views of the city.  there's a nice grassy area at the base of the hill right next to this awesome fenced in area w/ soft wood chips where you can take your dog off leash and let him run around w/ all the other dogs. good for those pets who like to pretend they're Houdini.  they have running water to fill up the doggie bowls too.

i like to walk here from my mission/upper market/deco ghetto neighborhood, pooch in tow.  this is also where the monthly Chihuahua Cha Cha is held - first sunday of the month, 12-3.
author: Suzanne A.

description: I'm not sure exactly what it is about this place, but I'm sooo enamored by it. I used to live just below it so I'd come up about once a week and stare at this beautiful city I love.  It has great views of the Mission, the Castro, and the Pac Heights area. It's also a great place to watch the fireworks, provided it's not too foggy!
author: Maia B.

description: What a great park!  It's not very big but very cool place with rocks to hike up, excellent views, and friendly dogs.. it feels like a mini hike in the middle of the city.
author: Engelbert H.

description: This is the best place to enjoy some quiet time with different views. Love to enjoy the various individual vegetable/flower gardens. Steep, steep hill, works off that chocolate calories.
author: miriam b.

description: I like to call this my secret spot. Even though it's totally not a secret. Despite the fact that it's right in the middle of the city and easily accessible, there have only been a couple of other people when I've been up there. It's like Twin Peaks, but without the tourists and fog.
author: reb f.

description: This is now my new favorite dog-walking destination!  Great dog-friendly area, including a fenced-in off-leash part.  The short climb to the top will put you on a large rock overlooking everything from North Beach to Potrero.  Unlike Tank Hill nearby -- the rock has many comfortable seats and perches -- even my beagle got to play mountain goat on it.
author: Eugene F.

description: The best part about Corona Heights might be that it's close to Tank Hill, so if you're entertaining guests from out of town, or just interested in exploring the geographic center of the city, it's really easy to combine the two locations. The panoramic view doesn't differ much from Tank, you still get to see downtown, the western addition, and all that stuff, but its lower elevation makes everything seem a bit more tangible, albeit, less lofty.
author: Alan L.

description: Great views, and I like watching the dogs play.  Also, it doesnt get too crowded and I dont ever worry I'm going to get dragged into the bushes. Unlike that Buena Vista park.
author: b s.

description: Home to Campbell hill, the perpetually brown guardian of Duboce Triangle and the Castro. Climb to the top to feel like you're hiking the great California wilderness , and surprise yourself at the crest with a stunning shot of the city.
author: Geronimo G.

description: Nature and urbanism intersect at the top of Corona Heights, the big rocky hill that hovers off to the right as you head southwest down Market.  Braving the windy path up the rocky slope at the park's center is well worth it--at the top is one of the best views in the city, high enough to make out the contours of the hills and get a whole new perspective on how San Francisco's streets and neighborhoods and landmarks relate to each other. The best part is being able to take it in without entering a building, instead perching on a jagged, windswept cliff in the middle of the city.
author: Emily L.

description: If you want a fantastic view of the city without the twin peak drive this is for you. Perched just above castro and overlooking the entire city and east bay this exquisite view is hard to beat. This park gives you the benefit of seeing city details without the city noise. Keep your eyes open for hummingbirds at the peak they are beautiful.
author: R J.

description:
shhhh.

don't tell anyone.

there are nice tennis courts at corona heights park.
author: Eric L.

description:
the view is the greatest thing that surprises me each time i visit. the view is astonishing, showing the best view of the eastern side of the city in fine detail. walking to the summit of the hill is what i do every time, stopping atop one of the rocks to sit on the breathe and enjoy the views. 

an enclosed dog park at the foot of the park so this park is really dog friendly.
author: Court L.

description: another san francisco's "green/secret spots". the view was amazing from the rocks. a small doggie park is located at the bottom of the hill and adjacent from this place is the randall museum. from the top, you could see bagdad cafe, dolores park, st. mary's cathedral, market street, tip of the bay bridge & etc...a great place to walk your dog or  just to sit on top of the rock to muse or contemplate.
author: Nelle A.

description: i come up here with my dog at least once a week. most of the time i drive even though i live 4 blocks away. sometimes i walk up the winding hills. when i say walk i mean, my dog drags my limp body face down in the asphalt cause i rarely do cardio when i go to the gym and can't handle the inclines. my ambition is left to how badly my dog wants to hump the neighborhood bitches. it has amazing views. it's completely gated so dogs can't run away like mine who think cause i am vietnamese i will eat him. you can hike up the red rocks after/before. there's also basket ball and tennis courts near by (not that you can actually play tennis there, i don't think those courts have been upgraded since the 60's). i heart san francisco. this is what i pay for to live here. even if it means i don't get groceries for a week.
author: dan T.

description: great views, good enclosed dog park, and trail hiking all in one.
author: Laura H.

description: full disclosure:  the house of hula is across the street from the city's best, (mostly) secret park.  that said, this park rocks.  from the plethora of dogs at all times to the fab views from the top, everything about this place is special.  huladog is tiny but thinks he's a giant and the truly giant dogs here are very patient with him trying to herd them.
author: nic f.

description: on top of the rock you feel like you OWN the city.  the neighborhood is well worth a walk-about as well.
author: Geoffrey W.
